channel.title: Software Development Principles on Michael Knapp's Home Page
channel.description: Recent content in Software Development Principles on Michael Knapp's Home Page

item.title: KISS and YAGNI
item.description: Prefer to keep your code as simple as possible.

item.title: Defensive Programming
item.description: Carefully consider the trade-offs of defensive programming patterns.

item.title: Single Responsibility Principle
item.description: Software components and classes should not be responsible for many concerns.

item.title: Open Closed Principle
item.description: Design software classes and components to be easily extended but rarely modified.

item.title: Substitution
item.description: Your code should be loosely coupled using abstractions, interfaces, and similar substitution principles.

item.title: Interface Segregation Principle
item.description: Function arguments should be minimal interfaces.

item.title: Software Testing
item.description: Your software should have ample automated tests across the board.

item.title: Configuration Levels
item.description: You should have ample controls over your code from configuration using expressions, templates, and scripts.

item.title: Judging Quality
item.description: You should routinely use automated tools to assess your code quality.

item.title: Class Stereotypes
item.description: Design your classes to follow effective patterns or stereotypes.

item.title: You Build You Own
item.description: Software developers should also be on the hook to support their applications.

item.title: Avoid Globals
item.description: Global variables create problems, you should avoid using them.

item.title: Premature Optimization
item.description: Avoid optimizing code before proving it is necessary.

item.title: Don't Reinvent the Wheel
item.description: Avoid duplication of efforts by leveraging open source.
